6/
With basic text mining, you could learned about Thai food, getting insight from unstructured text.

Of course, you‚Äôll want to supplement the data with an actual meal.

Recommendations belowüëá

5/
If you wanted a deeper dive into just Thai salads, you could: https://t.co/5DFd9WTQ3H

4/
How about the relationship between words?

You could see "nam" and "phrik" (chili sauce) had a strong relationship. Although "mu" is common, "mu" and "krop" (crispy pork) are especially related. ‚Äúkhao" and "phat" (fried rice) also highly related. https://t.co/pSUvbKhSvI

3/
Beyond frequency you could identify important words. One metric is the product of term frequency and inverse document frequency (tf-idf).

While pork ("mu") is common across many dishes, other materials are ranked higher in other dish types. https://t.co/8FFVc3Q5P7

2/
Pork ("mu") is common in many dishes, but there‚Äôs more rice ("khao") in individual dishes and more curry ("kaeng") in shared dishes. https://t.co/wuV1Dvc2ly

1/
You could learn about Thai food *just* from dish names.

Download names from Wikipedia, break into individual words (tokenization), tally and sort to find the most frequent words.

Pork (‚Äúmu‚Äù), curry ("kaeng"), stir-fry ("phat"), sauce ("nam"), and rice ("khao") are top 5. https://t.co/Zmd5gGShfe

What are some applications of Text Mining?

Here's an example featuring Thai food üáπüá≠üßµüëáüòã
